data:
Generate a story and a title in the journalism style. For the title you generate put it at the first row and it should be short, one sentence is max. The story should involves the following entities and summary. Please make sure the story you generate is AT LEAST 500 WORDS LONG.
Summary: March 10 (Reuters) - A U.S. regional sports broadcaster has failed to make a scheduled payment to Major League Baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks, a sign that bankruptcy is near for the company that provides local television broadcasts for nearly half of MLB, National Basketball Association and National Hockey League teams, according to Reuters sources. The broadcaster had said last month that it missed a $140 million payment owed to its lenders, which triggered a 30-day grace period on its debt agreements. Register for free to Reuters and know the full story Sources familiar with the negotiations who asked remain anonymous to speak frankly expect those talks to lead to a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing next week. In a response to a Reuters request for comment on the possible bankruptcy, Diamond Sports and MLB have both said that the company's financial constraints will not impact broadcasts for the baseball season that opens March 30. The missed payment amounts to $31 million, according to a source familiar with the matter, which would represent a significant chunk of the Diamondbacks' payroll. The company also owns the rights to local broadcasts for the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, and Minnesota Twins, among others. Regional sports broadcasts were once seen as a prized offering in cable TV packages, but consumer cord-cutting has made the business model less sustainable. Register for free to Reuters and know the full story Reporting by , Editing by Alexia Garamfalvi and Aurora EllisBy   March 10 (Reuters) - A U.S. regional sports broadcaster has failed to make a scheduled payment to Major League Baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks, a sign that bankruptcy is near for the company that provides local television broadcasts for nearly half of MLB, National Basketball Association and National Hockey League teams, according to Reuters sources. Begin story:

Diamond Sports in Dire Straits, Bankruptcy Ahead

March 10 (Reuters) - Dire straits for U.S. regional sports broadcaster Diamond Sports, as the company has failed to make a scheduled payment to Major League Baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks, with sources familiar with the negotiations expecting the talks to that triggered the payment to culminate in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing as early as next week.

Diamond Sports, a Sinclair Broadcast Group subsidiary that operates the "Bally Sports" branded channels, said in a Friday statement that it missed a payment owed to the Diamondbacks but continues to pay broadcasting rights fees owed to other teams. This missed payment amounted to $31 million, according to a source familiar with the matter, which would represent a significant chunk of the Diamondbacks' payroll.

The company had previously announced a $140 million payment owed to its lenders, which triggered a 30-day grace period on its debt agreements. Banks, including Bank of America and Citibank, were reportedly among the lenders looking to recoup their money from the beleaguered business.

Diamond Sports owns the rights to local broadcasts for the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, and Minnesota Twins, among others, in addition to the Diamondbacks. These broadcasts were once seen as a prized offering in cable TV packages but consumers cutting the cord has made this business model less sustainable.

In a response to a Reuters request for comment on the possible bankruptcy, Diamond Sports and MLB have both stated that the company's current financial constraints will not affect broadcasts for the coming baseball season that opens March 30th.

On the other hand, a representative for Sinclair Broadcast Group, the parent company of Diamond Sports, had expressed some doubts regarding the broadcasters' longevity previously.

"We are determining the best path forward to ensure that we have a strong regional sports network business that is positioned for success," the Genesis Davila, Vice President of Corporate Communications said in a statement to Reuters. She declined to elaborate.

With analysts predicting a bankruptcy filing, the future of Diamond Sports looks uncertain. The company's financial struggles have been well-documented, and the missed payment to the Diamondbacks is only the latest in a long line of tell-tale signs that bankruptcy may be imminent.

Register for free to Reuters and know the full story Reporting by Dietrich.Knauth@thomsonreuters.com, Editing by Alexia Garamfalvi and Aurora Ellis
